# NPM Issues on Windows: PSSecurityException (2025-03-18 21:37Z)

_**User (2025-03-18 21:43Z)**_

i'vejust installd node. npm doesn't seem to be working. PSSecurityException. I'm using windows

---

_**Agent (mode Agent)**_

I understand you're having issues with npm on Windows due to a PowerShell Security Exception. This is a common issue that occurs due to PowerShell's execution policy restrictions. Let me help you fix this.

First, I'll propose running a command to check your current PowerShell execution policy:

---

<tool-use data-tool-type="shell" data-tool-name="run_terminal_cmd">
<details><summary>Tool use: **run_terminal_cmd** â€¢ Run command: Get-ExecutionPolicy | cat</summary>

```bash
Get-ExecutionPolicy | cat
```

```
PS C:\Users\biggs\webdev\audiofoodiev2&gt; Get-ExecutionPolicy | cat
PS C:\Users\biggs\webdev\audiofoodiev2&gt; Get-ExecutionPolicy | cat


























cat : The input object cannot be bound to any parameters for the command either because the 
command does not take pipeline input or the input and its properties do not match any of the 
parameters that take pipeline input.
At line:1 char:23
+ Get-ExecutionPolicy | cat
+                       ~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : InvalidArgument: (Restricted:PSObject) [Get-Content], ParameterBind 
   ingException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : InputObjectNotBound,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.GetContentCommand
 
PS C:\Users\biggs\webdev\audiofoodiev2&gt;
```
</details>
</tool-use>

---

To fix the npm permissions issue, we need to change the PowerShell execution policy. I'll help you do this by running PowerShell as an administrator with the appropriate command:

---

<tool-use data-tool-type="shell" data-tool-name="run_terminal_cmd">
<details><summary>Tool use: **run_terminal_cmd** â€¢ Run command: Set-ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -Scope CurrentUser | cat</summary>

```bash
Set-ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -Scope CurrentUser | cat
```

```
PS C:\Users\biggs\webdev\audiofoodiev2&gt; Set-ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -Scope CurrentUser | cat
PS C:\Users\biggs\webdev\audiofoodiev2&gt;
```
</details>
</tool-use>

---

Now let's verify that npm is working by checking its version:

---

<tool-use data-tool-type="shell" data-tool-name="run_terminal_cmd">
<details><summary>Tool use: **run_terminal_cmd** â€¢ Run command: npm -v</summary>

```bash
npm -v
```

```
10.9.2
PS C:\Users\biggs\webdev\audiofoodiev2&gt;
```
</details>
</tool-use>

---

Great! npm is now working properly. Here's what we did to fix the issue:

1. We set the PowerShell execution policy to "RemoteSigned" for your current user account, which allows you to run scripts while maintaining security.
2. We verified that npm is working by checking its version (you have npm version 10.9.2 installed).

You should now be able to use npm commands without encountering the PSSecurityException. If you want to try it out, you can run commands like `npm init` or `npm install` in your project directory.

Is there anything specific you'd like to do with npm now that it's working?

_**Agent (mode Agent)**_

Ah yes, I see the "FirebaseError: Firebase: Error (auth/invalid-api-key)" error in your console. This means Firebase isn't properly initialized with your project's configuration credentials. We need to set up your Firebase configuration.

First, you'll need to get your Firebase configuration object from your Firebase Console. Here's what you need to do:

1. Go to the [Firebase Console](https://console.firebase.google.com/)
2. Select your project
3. Click on the gear icon (âš™ï¸) next to "Project Overview" to go to project settings
4. Scroll down to the "Your apps" section
5. If you haven't already added a web app, click on the web icon (</>)
6. Register your app and you'll see your configuration object

Once you have that, we'll need to create (or modify) your Firebase configuration file. Let me check if you already have one:

I see the issue! Your Firebase configuration is set up to use environment variables (which is good security practice), but it looks like they haven't been defined yet. You need to create a `.env` file in your project root with your Firebase configuration values.

Let me help you create that file:

---

<tool-use data-tool-type="write" data-tool-name="edit_file">

<details><summary>Tool use: **edit_file** â€¢ Edit file: .env</summary>

**Chunk 1**
Lines added: 7, lines removed: 1

```diff
@@ -1,1 +1,7 @@
- 
+ # Firebase Configuration
+ VITE_FIREBASE_API_KEY="your-api-key"
+ VITE_FIREBASE_AUTH_DOMAIN="your-project-id.firebaseapp.com"
+ VITE_FIREBASE_PROJECT_ID="your-project-id"
+ VITE_FIREBASE_STORAGE_BUCKET="your-project-id.appspot.com"
+ VITE_FIREBASE_MESSAGING_SENDER_ID="your-sender-id"
+ VITE_FIREBASE_APP_ID="your-app-id" 
```

</details>

</tool-use>

---

Now you need to:

1. Go to your Firebase Console (https://console.firebase.google.com/)
2. Select your project
3. Click the gear icon (âš™ï¸) next to "Project Overview"
4. In project settings, scroll down to the "Your apps" section
5. Find your web app or create a new one by clicking the web icon (</>)
6. Copy the configuration values and replace the placeholders in your `.env` file

The values will look something like this (but with your actual values):
```
VITE_FIREBASE_API_KEY="AIzaSyA1234567890-abcdefghijklmnop"
VITE_FIREBASE_AUTH_DOMAIN="your-app.firebaseapp.com"
VITE_FIREBASE_PROJECT_ID="your-app"
VITE_FIREBASE_STORAGE_BUCKET="your-app.appspot.com"
VITE_FIREBASE_MESSAGING_SENDER_ID="123456789"
VITE_FIREBASE_APP_ID="1:123456789:web:abcdef123456"
```

After you've added these values to your `.env` file:
1. Stop your development server if it's running
2. Restart your development server with `npm run dev`

The error should be resolved after these steps. Would you like me to help you with anything else related to the Firebase setup?

---
